Not five per cent. of it in some years is fit to be used by the millers of the country. The millers of the country know that, and the farmers know it. Still, some people get up to lecture us and tell us what to do and how to do it, who do not know anything at all themselves about saving wheat, or the facts in connection with it.

There is one other thing I want to talk about, and I want to ask the Minister for Finance seriously to consider the proposition that I make. He is giving a reduction on tea, but he is giving no reduction on sugar. I suggest to him that if he could reduce the tax upon sugar instead of upon tea it would be much more preferable, and I will give him some reasons for that. There is a considerable amount of raw material for the making of jams and the making of preserved fruits in this country, both wild and cultivated. There is no country, I think, in the world with so much wild fruit growing and going to waste on our hedge-rows as we have. There is no country I am acquainted with, and certainly no European country, where so much raw material could be utilised. If we got cheap sugar, and a little education and a little knowledge, all that raw material could be utilised in the country.

MainHeading.P: There was cheap sugar during the war, and people could get large quantities and get it at a cheap price and use it in the country to preserve Irish fruit. I think it would be hard to separate the one from the other, but if it were possible to separate sugar for preserving and sugar for ordinary use, it would be a great boon to this country. It would give to this country, to my mind, an industry that we have not had before without any cost, except merely the cost of the tins or the jars that would be necessary in preserving. I think that with a little education and a little help this could be made a national industry and brought into the homes of our rural population. We have cottage industries of all descriptions, some finding a market inside and some finding a market outside the country, some paying and some not paying. But I do suggest that we have here a fertile field for cottage industries. We have the raw material and we have a certain market, and if we have not sufficient market inside the country we can find a market outside the country. I think it is a thing that lends itself to cottage industry. Anybody travelling the country will see that we have a lot of hedges in Ireland, perhaps more than anywhere else. Ireland is remarkable for small fields and numerous fences, and we have a great amount of blackberries, crab apples, and an amount of wild fruit. I challenge any country in Europe to produce such quantities, and it is all practically going to waste. During the war many people were engaged in this particular industry: everybody will remember the number of people employed at it. But they were only engaged in collecting the raw material and sending it out of the country.

Even then an amount of people found a living at it for two or three months in the year. But after collecting the fruit their concern ended there. If they had anything to do with it afterwards it was only when it was manufactured. I do seriously suggest that here you have a line of industry that if developed—and it could be easily developed, and at very little expense— would give employment. Here is something I suggest that ought to engage the attention of the Government. Deputy Baxter referred to agriculture and other Deputies, I think, interrupted him. The fact is that the agricultural community produces the revenue and the other people of the country are only distributors of that revenue. But they only allow a certain amount of it to stick to the people engaged in it, while they always provide for themselves. They have a certain turnover, and they are always providing for a certain amount of profit, and the unfortunate man engaged in the industry has to take all the risks. On this question I do not knew whether the Ceann Comhairle will allow the discussion to be as wide as his deputy did. We were told of the milk standard of Irish cows, and of cows in other countries. I only refer to it in connection with the other reference made to the amount of money spent in pampering those engaged in agriculture. A great deal of that money was used by the heads of the Agricultural Department of that day in bringing a certain class of cattle into this country, which it is doubtful were for the benefit of the country. We were told by Deputy D'Alton that the average standard of the Irish cow at present varied from 420 to 470 gallons of milk, and that the standard in other countries was about 700 gallons.

I would like to know from the Department of Agriculture what the standard of Irish cows was 25 or 36 years ago, before we had such a boom in Shorthorns, of the purely beef type, which I maintain destroyed the Irish cow of that time and reduced the high standard of milk production. There is no question that the nursing of this type has deteriorated the milk producing capacity of Irish cows. Some Deputies referred to the money spent on agriculture. I would be more pleased if they used the word “mis-spent.” If the proposals of the Minister for Finance are purely an experiment in order to get information and to put this question beyond controversy, I would be satisfied to have that experiment. But I am opposed to the attitude adopted by Deputies Milroy and Sears. If the proposals mean, in the words of the Minister, that this is an experiment to test its merits for a year or for two or three years, I am perfectly prepared to give the experiment a fair trial. But if it means Protection, without any trial, if it means the thin end of the wedge, we on these Benches—and there may not be so few of us in the near future—will always oppose a policy of Protection that will not protect the main industry of the country.

Speaker.P: I only wish to remind the Minister and the Dáil of one incident that seems to be forgotten, and that was the Royal Commission that sat for many months and took evidence from the officials of the British Treasury and from officials in Ireland. That Commission found, to the great joy of the Irish Nation, that Ireland was overtaxed to the extent of 2¾ millions per year. Her taxable capacity was so far exceeded that prosperity would not have come under the British tyranny then reigning. Under the British tyranny in those days the sum total of taxation that was taken out of our pockets, farmers as well as industrialists, was only 10 millions. If Ireland was over-taxed—and we all believed in those days that it was over-taxed—by being taxed to the extent of 10 millions, I hope that when the Minister is drawing up his next Budget he will find time to read the Report signed by Mr. Childers and the evidence taken by that Commission. I would like to draw the attention of the Dáil to the fact that at the present time Denmark, which is about, the size of Ireland, and has about the same number of people as are in the Saorstát, is only taxed to the extent, even in those times of high prices and of extravagant administration, of 11 millions, and that the Minister is Budgeting for 27 millions in this unfortunate country.

I do not blame the Minister for the position in which he finds himself. A great many circumstances over which the Minister has no control have contributed to the pressure put upon him to find money by taxing boots, confectionery, jams and canned fruits, and increasing taxes that industrialists, as well as farmers, are bearing in this unfortunate country, while a Labour Government in England is able to reduce the tax on every article of food. I do not blame the Minister for the position in which he finds himself. I am a supporter of the Minister's policy which has put a stop to the cause of a great deal of the extravagance, namely, the general lawlessness of the country. The Minister deserves great credit for having put a stop to that, but he should bear in mind the fact that we are living on a elevated scale of extravagance in this country. We used to complain long ago in another place that the cost of Irish government was so extravagant under the British tyranny which we were then living under, when the Constabulary, instead of the Ministry we have now, were teaching the people the Ten Commandments, that we had to have 46 Departments to govern the country. We were promised that by co-ordination and one thing and another, those Departments would be reduced. What has happened since then? I have not got the Estimates before me. Perhaps Deputies can tell me.

Speaker.hpid: Sir JAMES CRAIG Sir JAMES CRAIG
Speaker.P: Fifty-six Departments.
Sixty.

We have now got sixty Departments. I think £250,000 have been placed at the disposal of one Department for relief works. There is no word of how it is to be spent. For public works, £650,000 is set aside to be raised in the present day and generation. We have 2d. to pay for postage stamps instead of 1½d. We have a Corporation tax, a legacy from the British, which the British have now abolished, of 1/- in the £ in addition to income tax. The Labour Government in England recognises the restriction that it puts upon trade and has removed that tax.
The Deputy should be careful, as he might be pointing a moral.

I would not object to a Labour Government removing the Corporation tax. If Deputies on the Labour Benches were in power and removed the Corporation tax, reduced the sugar tax, took the tax off coffee, took 4d. instead of 3d. off tea, I would be delighted. In addition, the Labour Government have taken off the Inhabited House duty so as to encourage the building of houses. They did not offer subsidies, but took off the tax. This experiment, I ascertained the other day, was protective. To be even an experiment it must be definite from the point of time because, as was pointed out from the benches opposite, nobody is going to build a boot factory, a confectionery factory, or a bottle factory, unless there is some guarantee that this policy is going to continue. I suggested to the Minister that he should give us an idea of how long this experiment is going to last. It is definite in point of time and is likely to be extended in its area to other commodities. It cannot stop where it is. Take the tax of 33? on motor bodies. A great many of my constituents are building carriage bodies for the Great Southern and Western Railway, whose works at Inchicore are the largest in Ireland. Do you think that these men will be satisfied to see the bodies of wagons or carriages ever again imported into this country? Do you think that I, as their representative, will not be claiming protection for that great industry at Inchicore? Of course, I will, and of course they will. It is natural and to be expected that representatives of the farming industry will be asking for protection. As time goes on there is not an industry in this country that will not ask for protection. We are definitely committed to protection. The country might as well make up its mind that we are definitely committed to protection. In the case of the tax on soap, the soap factories are largely in the hands of trusts. The trusts were not working the soap factories in this country to their full extent. In order to provide employment a tax of 10 per cent. was put on soap. That 10 per cent is taken from the consumers of soap and is an inducement to have the soap factories here worked to their full extent. A friend of mine in another industry whose name I am not going to mention, put the same case to me. He said that in twelve months' time his business, which is part of a trust, will be closed down unless he gets protection. Take the case of cement. Cement is controlled by a ring. Cement factories in this country are closed. Why not put a tax on cement in order to open the Irish cement factories? There is a paper factory at Clondalkin. Why not put a tax on paper in order to open the Irish factories? Why not put a tax on all these things and make the general taxpayer pay so as to induce trusts and rings and manufacturers of all kinds to open up business and build this wall around the country? Such a wall reminds me of the great wall that the Chinese built around their country at the time when Chinese progress and improvements ceased, two thousand years ago. The building of a wall around a small country like Ireland, where we live by taking in one anothers' washing, may lead to some increase of employment, but it will also lead to the loss of a great deal of the luxuries and comforts that are now enjoyed by the people under a system of free exports and free imports.

MainHeading.P: I am not an extreme Protectionist, nor am I an extreme Free Trader. I have my convictions, and I keep to my convictions. At my election I was opposed by an extreme Protectionist. I understood from the Government then that they kept an open mind on the matter, and it is on that ground that the Government still regard this as an experiment. They have still an open mind, and I am supporting the Minister and the Budget. I am not an extreme Free Trader. The Minister should use the tax on sugar entirely as a Customs tax, and he should treat the tobacco tax in the same way, and leave to the farming community in Ireland the free growth of both sugar and beet. He will thus touch the primary and greatest industry and enable beet sugar and beet factories to be put on their feet. When and if the Minister, by a system of Protection, is able to establish in this country a new industry and nurse it through its infant years, then he may remove the tax and give the community the benefit of the industry which he started. In the same way there are other industries of a more industrial nature, new industries that should be protected in their early infancy. I am not prepared to say that the boot and shoe industry is not one of them, but if the Minister thinks that a general policy of Protection leading to a Budget of £30,000,000 a year is ever going to bring peace and prosperity to this country, he will find he is very much mistaken. The gentlemen who are advocating, as everybody advocated in the old days, reduction of taxation, will find the people of the country behind them, and they will cause this country to rise to the level of Denmark, the successful competitor of this country, not alone in agriculture, but in some other industries also. I think their merchant ships number 379 vessels. They have a fleet and army. They provide free education, and yet all the taxes they raise amount to £11,000,000, while the Minister raises £30,000,000 in taxes.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - FILM TRADE COMPLAINTS.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. ALFRED BYRNE Mr. ALFRED BYRNE
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make arrangements for the appointment of a Committee of Members of the Dáil to investigate the complaints of the film trade, and to make recommendations that will enable censoring of films to be carried on in a place and in a manner satisfactory to the trade and public alike.

I assume that the complaints of the film trade referred to by the Deputy are those concerned with: (1) import duty on films; (2) fees charged by the proprietors of the Dame Street Bonded Stores for bonding services; (3) entertainments tax; (4) arrangements and charge for censorship.

(1) and (3) are Revenue matters with which my Department is not concerned; (2) is not a Government matter at all. There is no obligation on film importers to utilise the Dame Street premises as a bonded store, just as there is no obligation on importers of tea to bond in any given bonded store. All that has happened is that the Revenue Commissioners on application have approved of the Dame Street premises as satisfying their requirements for a bonded store. The fees charged for bonding are not fixed by any Government Department. They are entirely a commercial matter.

As regards (4), I have to refer the Deputy to a long statement which I made to the Dáil on the 5th March last arising out of questions addressed to me by Deputy Hewat and others. I explained in that statement what arrangements had been made for censorship, and how they had been made. I also said that if experience proves that lower fees will suffice or cheaper arrangements for censorship can be made the contract with the Irish Bonded Film Store, Limited, will not be renewed when it expires.

In these circumstances, I am unable to see what useful purpose could be served by appointing such a committee as the Deputy mentions. Does the Deputy suggest that the contract already entered into should be broken?

Speaker.hpid: PADRAIG O hOGAIN (An Clár) PADRAIG O hOGAIN (An Clár)
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Agriculture if he is in a position to state whether Mr. Timothy Crowe, 25 Sarsfield Street, Limerick, furnished the particulars required by the Land Act of 1923 to the Land Commission in respect of his estate at Parteen, Co. Clare. If not, if he will state how do the tenants on that estate stand in respect of that Act; and what steps he proposes to take in the matter, and when such steps may be taken.

Particulars were furnished by the owner to the Land Commission for the purposes of the collection of compounded arrears of rent in respect of a holding situate at Parteen, County Limerick, on the estate mentioned. However, as it appeared that the tenant held under a lease for a term of years of which more than sixty were unexpired at the date of the passing of the Land Act, 1923, the holding did not come within the definition of “tenanted land” under Section 73 (2) of the Act, and, consequently, the tenant was not entitled to the reduction given under Sections 19 and 20 of the Act to tenants of holdings to which the Act applies. Under Section 38 of the Act an application may be made on the prescribed form to the Land Commission for the purpose of redeeming the rent payable under the lease.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - DEPENDENT'S ALLOWANCE.

Speaker.hpid: AODH O CULACHAIN AODH O CULACHAIN
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he is aware that Mrs. Sarah Coogan, 70 Married Quarters, K Line, Curragh Camp, has not received any dependent's allowance in respect of her son, John Coogan, Army No. R. 451, who attested 12th July, 1922, and was discharged 27th July, 1923, and whether he will ask for further inquiries for verification of earnings and contributions to the home from the manager of the Canteen Board, where Coogan was employed prior to enlistment, with a view to payment of arrears.

It has been ascertained from the Manager of the Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes, Belfast, that John Coogan was employed by that body from the 7th July, 1919, to the 12th November, 1921. In the absence of any evidence of her son's earnings from the 12th November up to the date of attestation the decision to reject Mrs. Coogan's claim for dependent's allowance must be maintained.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - SOLDIER'S GRATUITY.

Speaker.hpid: AODH O CULACHAIN AODH O CULACHAIN
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he is aware of the inadequate gratuity of £25 awarded Private Patrick Doyle, of Kilcullen, Co. Kildare; further, if the Medical Board has recommended this man for treatment, as there are still one or two bullets that have not yet been extracted from his leg, and whether he will order medical treatment until he is cured or award him a pension.

The Medical Board which examined Patrick Doyle found that his degree of disablement is less than 20 per cent., and he is, therefore, not entitled to a pension. The Board also found that Doyle's case does not require medical treatment, as his disability is in a final condition. I regret that it is not practicable to increase the amount of gratuity already awarded.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - RAILWAY TRIBUNAL AND CANALS.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. JAMES O'MARA Mr. JAMES O'MARA
Speaker.P: asked the President of the Executive Council whether he will consider including the Grand Canal Company and all other companies controlling navigable inland waterways in the Saorstát within the jurisdiction of the railway tribunal.

As I stated in my speech on the Second Reading of the Railways Bill, the railway tribunal will have, in effect, much the same jurisdiction over inland waterways as over railways. The tribunal will exercise all the former powers of the Railway and Canal Commission in regard to canals and inland navigations. It will not actually fix charges of the Grand Canal, the Royal Canal, and the Shannon Navigation, which are controlled by orders issued by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, but the Bill provides that before revising such Orders the Minister shall refer the question for advice to the tribunal, and further provides that any rates granted by the amalgamated company which may be considered detrimental to inland navigations, may be varied or cancelled by the tribunal. For the purpose of dealing with these matters, the tribunal will include a member representing the Canal and Inland Navigation Companies and Authorities in the Saorstát, and a representative of the particular public interest concerned.
